chapter.title: Text Messaging
chapter.para: Text messaging is a common feature of practically all communications protocols. In Telepathy it is done using text channels. See for a description of how to set up a text channel.
Telepathy provides two APIs for text messaging. The preferred API is the new Messages interface, which provides for rich-text messages, attachments and other messaging capabilities.
The second API is the simple interface. This API only supports plain text messages, and no advanced features like attachments and may be deprecated in the future.

tip.para: Some connection managers do not currently support Messages. If your client needs to be compatible with older connection managers, it is advisable to implement both interfaces.

sect1.title: Rich Text Interface

note.para: The Messages interface is the preferred interface for text messaging, because it supports the full range of messaging features exposed by the protocols.

Some older connection managers may not support this interface. If this is the case, or if you really only want to send simple messages (e.g. for a status reporting system), you can use the simple messaging interface documented below.

sect1.para: Telepathy provides support for rich-text messaging via the Messages interface. Rich-text messaging can include features like formatted (rich text) messages, alternatives (similar to MIME's multipart/alternative) and attachments. Messages are formatted in XHTML-IM.

sect2.title: Message Structure
sect2.para: Messages are sent and received as an array of Message_Part key-value mappings, the first of which contains the message headers. shows an example message.

example.title: Example Message
example.para: An example message consisting of four Message_Parts: the headers, two alternatives and an attachment.

row.entry:
"""Here is a photo of my cat:

Isn't it cute?"""
"""Here is a photo of my cat:\n[IMG: lol!]\nIsn't it cute?"""

sect2.para: The known headers for a message are:

row.entry: An opaque, globally-unique identifier for the entire message. Which may be treated the same as a MIME message-id for the mid: and cid: URI schemes. Not always present.
The time the message was sent and received respectively. May not be present if a time cannot be determined.
The handle id of the contact who sent the message. May be 0 or ommitted, if the sender cannot be determined.
The type of message. Defaults to Channel_Text_Message_Type_Normal if ommitted.

The incoming message ID, only valid for as long as the message is unacknowledged.
This header is important for acknowledging the received message.
This message is specific to the given interface, which is neither Text nor Messages. This key can also appear in subsequent parts of the message.
If true, the incoming message was part of a replay of message history. Defaults to false.
If true, the incoming message has been seen in a previous channel during the lifetime of the Connection, but had not been acknowledged when that channel closed. Defaults to false.

sect2.para: Alternatives with the same name should be ordered from highest fidelity to lowest fidelity (i.e. rich text before plain text). Clients should display the first alternative they understand.

sect2.title: Receiving Messages
sect2.para: When a remote user initiates a new text chat, Telepathy will automatically create a new channel for the chat, who's creation will be heralded by the NewChannels signal. Filter on the channels given for channels of type Channel_Type_Text. shows how to discover this channel.
Set up a D-Bus proxy for the channel, like you would for any other channel (see ). Check to ensure that the Messages interface is available.

Incoming messages are announced with the MessageReceived signal, which places them on the pending message queue. To remove messages from the pending message queue, they must be acknowledged with Text.AcknowledgePendingMessages. There will already be messages pending, the ones that caused the creation of the channel. These can be accessed via the PendingMessages property. See .
The message id to acknowledge the message is contained in the headers of the message as the key pending-message-id (see ).

important.title: Always Acknowledge Messages
important.para: You must always acknowledge a received message, but you should only do so after you have attempted to parse it.
Failure to acknowledge a message will result in a new channel being created with the pending messages when the current channel is closed.

It's posssible that a bug in your application's message parser could cause an application crash. You should attempt to parse the message before acknowledging it. Thus, if your application has a crash, the message will still be pending when the client reloads.

sect1.title: Simple Messaging Interface
sect1.para: The simple messaging interface allows the sending and receiving of simple (plain/unformatted) text messages. All of its features are also available in the more powerful rich text interface, which is not complex for plain text messaging. Where possible you should use the newer interface instead.

warning.title: Possible Candidate for Deprecation
warning.para: The methods of this interface are a possible candidate for future deprecation.

The rich text interface, Messages provides all of the functionality that is provided by this interface. The Messages interface is not significantly more complex for the case of simple text messaging, and should be used in preference to this interface.

sect2.title: Receiving Messages
sect2.para: The creation of a new text channel will be heralded by the NewChannels signal. Filter on the new channels for channels of type Channel_Type_Text (see ).

Incoming messages are announced with the Received signal on the Channel.Type.Text interface. This is emmitted at the same time as Messages.MessageReceived (if for some reason you have both signals connected).

row.entry: The ID used to acknowledge the message, this is the same ID as pending-message-id in the rich interface.
The time the message was received. The same as message-received.
The handle of the message sender. The same as message-sender.
The type of the message: normal, action, notice, auto-reply or delivery report. The same as message-type.
The message content as plain text.
